stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the 3D layout of a milk bar saloon for the cowboy-themed level, planning a secret room and new enemy mechanics. He also discussed a major pivot in level theme philosophy for the game's later stages and a planned rework of a section in Course 2.

development_findings.summary: A secret room is being designed for the saloon where enemies secretly drink 'chalky milk,' an illegal parody of the bar's normal milk. The entrance will be a hidden doorknob on a wall.
development_findings.quote: There's going to be a secret room where a bunch of bad guys sit around the table drinking chalky milk.

development_findings.summary: A new gameplay mechanic was conceived on-stream: Dry Bones in the cowboy level will be stronger due to a lifetime of 'drinking milk,' requiring a ground pound to defeat instead of a normal jump.
development_findings.quote: Oh shit, what if the Dry Bones are harder to beat in the space because of all the milk they drank when they were alive?

development_findings.summary: Kaze is rethinking the themes for later courses, feeling his current ideas (music level, casino, comic book) are uninspired. He wants to return to the 'dream-inspired' creative process from his previous hack, Lost Impact.
development_findings.quote: I find that some of the other themes I had planned for course 13, 14, 14 and the side level. Maybe they're also a little bit uninspired compared to how they were in Lost Impact.

development_findings.summary: A new level concept being seriously considered is a moving space station or shuttle, involving gravity mechanics and combat against space pirates.
development_findings.quote: The last idea I had was that it would be like a space station, like a space shuttle. Maybe you can do some gravity fuckery in here and you would help like friendly NPCs in the space station fight against space pirates or whatever.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has decided to completely rework a 'lame' water raft section in Course 2, replacing it with a more engaging platforming challenge using 'fling vines'.
development_findings.quote: We're gonna rework part of course 2. The Divine Dino Domain. There's an inside section where it's just like a water raft going around and you collect red coins. It's lame as fuck. Instead, it's gonna be mostly a platforming section.

development_findings.summary: Kaze firmly rejects ideas for levels that are direct references or crossovers from other franchises like Pok√©mon.
development_findings.quote: I'm not just putting a Pokemon level. The hell?

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that the act of creation is the fundamental purpose of human existence.
context_findings.quote: What would be the point of an existence where you don't create? That's like the whole purpose of the human soul. And you're gonna go without it? Damn. Are you even alive anymore at that point?

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a personal ethical stance that since he modifies Nintendo's IP without permission, he cannot object if others modify his work without his permission.
context_findings.quote: I feel like if you hack someone else's game without their consent you should also be fine with someone hacking your hack against your consent. That seems logical to me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is committed to developing within the N64's original hardware limitations, viewing it as a core part of the creative challenge.
context_findings.quote: I'm not interested in ever using more than 8MB just because the original N64 games didn't do it. And going beyond the original limitations is just kinda against the spirit of the challenge.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is a proponent of using AI tools like ChatGPT for development, viewing it as a 'better Google' for efficiency in tasks like generating code snippets and refining dialogue.
context_findings.quote: I feel like people that saying it's useless are just coping maybe because they're useless.

context_findings.summary: Kaze sells merchandise through Pixel Empire and expresses brief concern over who assumes the legal liability for selling products based on Nintendo's IP.
context_findings.quote: I always ask them, are you sure this is fine? And they say yes. With those stickers, I also asked them like, do you guys think it would be fine? Maybe I should trust them less actually, now that I think about it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reveals the game's original story involved a 'slavery plot' which he now feels is too dark and needs to be overhauled.
context_findings.quote: The whole slavery plot is a little bit dark for a Mario game. Actually, we can just reuse this texture now. Yeah, I think I like this.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses strong disdain for conventional music and color theory, calling them 'invented' and 'fiction.' He prefers composing with raw frequencies and judging colors based on 'color science' rather than the color wheel.
context_findings.quote: I find it's only two thousand three hundred dollars Can I clear a music theory throw them both out

biobak.summary: Kaze directly references a specific 'window technique' developed by Biobak that he wants to implement in the saloon level.
biobak.quote: Dude, Biobak, we need to use your window technique here. Look at this. It's so perfect, dude.

biobak.summary: Kaze makes a specific technical art decision to not use one of Biobak's 'combiner' methods for the saloon floor in order to achieve a multi-texture effect.
biobak.quote: Unfortunately I can't use biomex combiner. It's not gonna work in this situation. Because I do want the multi textured floor.

badub.summary: Badub's music for the game is highly praised by Kaze and the community.
badub.quote: Everything Banduke makes a banger, true.

badub.summary: Kaze is considering creating and selling a physical N64 cartridge of the game's soundtrack, and states he would pay Badub for his work on the OST if this happens.

zeina.summary: Kaze confirms on-stream that Zeina is responsible for creating the animations for the Dry Bones enemies.
zeina.quote: Are you also doing the drybones animations? In the shambler I have one smaller room that's like 2.5k. Wow. But that's no problem because it's all rooms. Same as here. Doesn't matter. Oh, okay Zeina. Skel sounds good.

zeina.summary: Zeina contributes ideas for merchandise, having suggested the 'I hate video games' sticker design.
zeina.quote: Zayna thought the I hate video game thing is good.

key_stories.title: The Milk-Strengthened Dry Bones
key_stories.summary: An idea from the community led Kaze to design a new mechanic for the Dry Bones enemies in the cowboy level. He decided they would be strengthened by milk, requiring a ground pound to defeat, and then used AI to craft the dialogue for an NPC who explains this lore to the player.
key_stories.challenge: The enemies in the cowboy level needed a unique, theme-appropriate gameplay mechanic.
key_stories.process: A viewer's idea about milk making bones stronger sparked the concept. Kaze decided this would translate to requiring a ground pound for defeat. To communicate this to the player, he planned an NPC and used ChatGPT to refine the dialogue to sound like a cowboy.
key_stories.outcome: A new enemy variant was created with a specific weakness (ground pound) tied directly to the level's lore (drinking milk), which will be explained to the player by an NPC with custom, AI-assisted dialogue.
key_stories.key_quote: Howdy partner, just a bit of cowboy wisdom for you them dry bones up on them hills they're tough as all leather spent their days guzzling milk so wrecking your little hops ain't gonna make a dent.

key_stories.title: Finding Inspiration in Dreams
key_stories.summary: Feeling that his planned level themes were growing stale, Kaze reflected on his past work and realized his most creative ideas came from dreams. He decided to abandon his current plans and pursue a new, more 'inspired' concept: a level set on a moving space station.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze felt the planned themes for later levels in the game were becoming 'uninspired' and derivative.
key_stories.process: Kaze reflected on the creative process for his previous major project, *Lost Impact*, and identified that its most successful level themes came from his dreams. He decided to apply this same method to RTYI, leading him to brainstorm and commit to a new space-themed level.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze pivoted the design direction for the game's later stages, scrapping several ideas like a music or casino level in favor of a new, more exciting 'space station' concept that felt more creatively inspired.
key_stories.key_quote: I thought back to how I came up with the Lost Impact themes. And usually all the themes in Lost Impact were just things that literally came to me in a dream. That's probably why they feel so inspired to me.

key_stories.title: The Hacker's Code
key_stories.summary: Kaze explained his personal code of ethics regarding ROM hacking. He believes that because his own work is an unauthorized modification of Nintendo's property, he has no moral standing to prevent others from modifying his work in turn.
key_stories.challenge: The morality and ethics of modding and using others' work in the ROM hacking scene was questioned.
key_stories.process: When the topic of hacking other hacks came up, Kaze explained his reasoning. He believes that by modifying a company's IP without consent, a modder forfeits their right to complain if their own work is subsequently modified by others without their consent.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze articulated a firm, consistent personal philosophy on intellectual property within the hacking community.
key_stories.key_quote: I feel like if someone makes a hack then everyone should just be allowed to use that guy's hack and there's nothing he can do because he did it against nintendo's consent so if you complain about people using your hack for something you're just being a little bitch.
